FedPerm: Private and Robust Federated Learning by Parameter Permutation

Hamid Mozaffari1, Virendra J. Marathe2, Dave Dice2 The work was done while interning at the Oracle Labs.
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables mutually untrusting clients to collaboratively train a common machine learning model. Client data privacy is paramount in FL. At the same time, the model must be protected from poisoning attacks from adversarial clients. Existing solutions address these two problems in isolation. We present FedPerm, a new FL algorithm that addresses both these problems by combining a novel intra-model parameter shuffling technique that amplifies data privacy, with Private Information Retrieval (PIR) based techniques that permit cryptographic aggregation of clientsâ€™ model updates. The combination of these techniques further helps the federation server constrain parameter updates from clients so as to curtail effects of model poisoning attacks by adversarial clients. We further present FedPermâ€™s unique hyperparameters that can be used effectively to trade off computation overheads with model utility. Our empirical evaluation on the MNIST dataset demonstrates FedPermâ€™s effectiveness over existing Differential Privacy (DP) enforcement solutions in FL.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm where mutually untrusting clients collaborate to train a shared model, called the global model, without explicitly sharing their local training data. FL training involves a server that aggregates, using an aggregation rule (AGR), model updates that the clients compute using their local private data. The aggregated global model is thereafter broadcasted by the server to a subset of the clients. This process repeats for several rounds until convergence or a threshold number of rounds. Though highly promising, FL faces multiple challengesÂ (Kairouz etÂ al. 2019) to its practical deployment. Two of these challenges are (i) data privacy for clientsâ€™ training data, and (ii) robustness of the global model in the presence of malicious clients.

The data privacy challenge emerges from the fact that raw model updates of federation clients are susceptible to privacy attacks by an adversarial server as demonstrated by several recent worksÂ (Li etÂ al. 2022; Lim and Chan 2021; Nasr, Shokri, and Houmansadr 2019; Wei etÂ al. 2020; Zhu, Liu, and Han 2019). Two classes of approaches can address this problem in significantly different ways: First, Local Differential PrivacyÂ (Duchi, Jordan, and Wainwright 2013; Kasiviswanathan etÂ al. 2008; Truex etÂ al. 2020; Warner 1965) in FL (LDP-FL) enforces a strict theoretical privacy guarantee to model updates of clients. The guarantee is enforced by applying carefully calibrated noise to the clientsâ€™ local model updates using a local randomizer â„›â„›\mathcal{R}. In addition to the privacy guarantee, LDP-FL can defend against poisoning attacks by malicious clients, thus providing robustness to the global model Â (Nguyen etÂ al. 2021; Naseri, Hayes, and DeÂ Cristofaro 2020; Sun etÂ al. 2019). However, the model update perturbation needed for the LDP guarantee significantly degrades model utility.

The other approach to enforce client data privacy is secure aggregation (sAGR), where model update aggregation is done using cryptographic techniques such as homomorphic encryption or secure multi-party computationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al. 2017; Zhang etÂ al. 2020; Bell etÂ al. 2020; Fereidooni etÂ al. 2021). sAGR protects privacy of clientsâ€™ data from an adversarial server because the server sees just the encrypted version of clientsâ€™ model updates. Moreover, this privacy is enforced without compromising global model utility. However, the encrypted model updates themselves provide the perfect cover for a malicious client to poison the global modelÂ (Fereidooni etÂ al. 2021; Nguyen etÂ al. 2021) â€“ the server cannot tell the difference between a honest model update and a poisoned one since both are encrypted.

In this paper we answer the dual question: Can we design an efficient federated learning algorithm that achieves local privacy for participating clients at a low utility cost, while ensuring robustness of the global model from malicious clients? To that end, we present FedPerm, a new FL protocol that combines LDPÂ (Duchi, Jordan, and Wainwright 2013; Kasiviswanathan etÂ al. 2008; Warner 1965), model parameter shufflingÂ (Erlingsson etÂ al. 2019), and computational Private Information Retrieval (cPIR)Â (Chor and Gilboa 1997; Chang 2004; Aguilar-Melchor etÂ al. 2016; Angel etÂ al. 2018) in a novel way to achieve our dual goals.

The starting point of FedPermâ€™s design is privacy amplification by shufflingÂ (Erlingsson etÂ al. 2019), which enables stronger (i.e., amplified) privacy with little model perturbation (using randomizer â„›â„›\mathcal{R}) at each client. Crucially, our shuffling technique fundamentally differs from prior works in that we apply intra-model parameter shuffling rather that the inter-model parameter shuffling done previouslyÂ (Erlingsson etÂ al. 2019; Liu etÂ al. 2021; Girgis etÂ al. 2021).

Next, each FedPerm client privately chooses its shuffling pattern uniformly at random for each FL round. To aggregate the shuffled (and perturbed) model parameters, FedPerm client utilizes cPIR to generate a set of PIR queries for its shuffling pattern that allows the server to retrieve each parameter privately during aggregation. All the server observes is the shuffled parameters of the model update for each participating client, and a series of PIR queries (i.e., the encrypted version of the shuffling patterns). The server can aggregate the PIR queries and their corresponding shuffled parameters for multiple clients to get the encrypted aggregated model. The aggregated model is decrypted independently at each client.

The combination of LDP at each client and intra-model parameter shuffling achieves enough privacy amplification to let FedPermÂ preserve high model utility. At the same time, availability of the shuffled parameters at the federation server lets it control a clientâ€™s model update contribution by enforcing norm-bounding, which is known to be highly effective against model poisoning attacksÂ (Nguyen etÂ al. 2021; Naseri, Hayes, and DeÂ Cristofaro 2020; Sun etÂ al. 2019).

Since FedPermÂ utilizes cPIR which relies on homomorphic encryption (HE)Â (Paillier 1999; DamgÃ¥rd and Jurik 2001), it can be computationally expensive, particularly for large models. We present computation/utility trade off hyper-parameters in FedPerm, that enables us to achieve an interesting trade off between computational efficiency and model utility. In particular, we can adjust the computation burden for a proper utility goal by altering the size and number of shuffling patterns for the FedPerm clients.

We empirically evaluate FedPerm on the MNIST dataset to demonstrate that it is possible to provide LDP-FL guarantees at low model utility cost. We theoretically and numerically demonstrate a trade off between model utility and computational efficiency. Specifically, FedPermâ€™s hyperparameters create shuffling windows whose size can be reduced to drastically cut computation overheads, but at the cost of reducing model utility due to lower privacy amplification. We experiment with two representative shuffling window configurations in FedPermâ€“ â€œlightâ€ and â€œheavyâ€. For a (4.0,10âˆ’5)4.0superscript105(4.0,10^{-5})-LDP guarantee, the light version of FedPerm, where client encryption, and server aggregation needs 52.252.252.2 seconds and 212121 minutes respectively, results in a model that delivers 32.85%percent32.8532.85\% test accuracy on MNIST. The heavier version of FedPerm, where client encryption and server aggregation needs 32.132.132.1 minutes and 16.416.416.4 hours respectively, results in 72.38%percent72.3872.38\% test accuracy. Non-private FedAvg, CDP-FL and LDP-FL provide 91.02%percent91.0291.02\%, 53.50%percent53.5053.50\%, and 13.74%percent13.7413.74\% test accuracies for the same (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP guarantee respectively.

2.2 Local Differential Privacy in FL (LDP-FL)

CDP-FL relies on availability of a trusted server for collecting raw model updates. 2.3 Privacy Amplification by Shuffling Clientsâ€™ updates

Recent worksÂ (Liu etÂ al. 2021; Girgis etÂ al. 2021) utilize the privacy amplification effect by shuffling model parameters across client model updates from participating clients to improve the LDP-FL utility (illustrated in FigureÂ 1(c)). FL frameworks based on shuffling clientsâ€™ updates consists of three building processes: â„³=ğ’œâˆ˜ğ’®âˆ˜â„›â„³ğ’œğ’®â„›\mathcal{M}=\mathcal{A}\circ\mathcal{S}\circ\mathcal{R}. Specifically, they introduce a shuffler ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}, which sits between the FL clients and the FL server, and it shuffles the locally perturbed updates (by randomizer â„›â„›\mathcal{R}) before sending them to the server for aggregation (ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}). More specifically, given parameter index iğ‘–i, ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} randomly shuffles the itâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th} parameters of model updates received from the nğ‘›n participant clients. The shuffler thus detaches the model updates from their origin client (i.e. anonymizes them). Previous worksÂ (Balle etÂ al. 2019a; Balcer and Cheu 2019; Ghazi, Pagh, and Velingker 2019) focused on shuffling one-dimensional data xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X, and corollaryÂ 2.1 shows the privacy amplification effect by shuffling.

From above corollary, the privacy amplification has a direct relationship with nğ‘›\sqrt{n} where nğ‘›n is the number of selected clients for aggregation, i.e., increasing the number of clients will increase the privacy amplification. 3 FedPerm: Private and Robust Federated Learning by parameter Permutation

We assume a dual threat model setting where (i) the federation server acts as an honest but curious aggregator, and (ii) the federation clients can maliciously attempt to poison the trained model using manipulated local parameter updates.

3.1 FedPerm: Design

FedPerm utilizes computational Private Information Retrieval (cPIR)Â (Chor and Gilboa 1997; Stern 1998) for secure aggregation at the federation server. In particular, FedPermÂ uses the cPIR algorithm by ChangÂ (Chang 2004) that leverages the algorithm by PaillierÂ (Paillier 1999). AlgorithmÂ 1 depicts FedPerm. FigureÂ 1(d) depicts the FedPerm framework that consists of three components, â„±=ğ’œâˆ˜ğ’®âˆ˜â„›dâ„±ğ’œğ’®superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{A}\circ\mathcal{S}\circ\mathcal{R}^{d}, denoting the client-side parameter randomizer (â„›dsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{R}^{d}), the client-side shuffler (ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}), and the server-side aggregator (ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}).

Key Distribution Paillier is a partial HE (PHE) algorithm that relies on a public key encryption scheme (details of Paillier HE in AppendixÂ D.3). Since Paillier is employed to protect client updates from a curious federation server, FedPermÂ requires an independent key server that generates a pair of public and secret homomorphic keys (Pâ€‹k,Sâ€‹k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘†ğ‘˜(Pk,Sk). This key pair is distributed to all federation clients, and just the public key Pâ€‹kğ‘ƒğ‘˜Pk is sent to the federation server (for aggregation). The key server itself can be implemented as an independent third party server, or a leader among the federation clients may be chosen to play that roleÂ (Zhang etÂ al. 2020).

Client Local Training: In the ttâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„t^{th} round, the server randomly samples nğ‘›n clients among total Nğ‘N clients. Each sampled client locally retrains a copy of the global model it receives from the server (Î¸gtsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘”ğ‘¡\theta_{g}^{t}), optimizing the model using its local data and local learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta (AlgorithmÂ 1, line 5).

Randomizing Update Parameters: After computing local updates Î¸utsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¢ğ‘¡\theta_{u}^{t}, client uğ‘¢u clips the update using threshold Cğ¶C and normalizes the parameters to the range [0,1]01[0,1] (AlgorithmÂ 1, lines 6-7). Now the client applies the randomizer (i.e., â„›dsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{R}^{d}) on its local parameters to make them (Îµd)subscriptğœ€ğ‘‘(\varepsilon_{d})-differentially private (AlgorithmÂ 1, line 8). We use the Laplacian Mechanism as a local randomizer with privacy budget Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}.

Shuffling: After clipping and perturbing the local update, each client shuffles the parameters yutsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¢ğ‘¡y_{u}^{t} using the random shuffling pattern Ï€usubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¢\pi_{u} (AlgorithmÂ 1, lines 9-10). Shuffling amplifies the privacy budget Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}, which we discuss in SectionÂ 4.

Generating PIR queries: Now the client encodes the shuffle indices Ï€usubscriptğœ‹ğ‘¢\pi_{u} using a PIR protocol. This process comprises two steps: first creating a binary mask of the shuffled index, and then encrypting it using the public key of HE that the client received in first step (AlgorithmÂ 1 line 11-12). Generally, a PIR client needs access to the jtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j^{th} record privately from an untrusted PIR server that holds a dataset Î¸ğœƒ\theta with dğ‘‘d records; i.e. the PIR server cannot know that the client requested the jtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j^{th} record. To do so, the PIR client creates a unit vector (binary mask) bâ†’jsubscriptâ†’ğ‘ğ‘—\vec{b}_{j} of size dğ‘‘d where all the bits are set to zero except the jtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j^{th} position being set to one:

Prior worksÂ (Nguyen etÂ al. 2021; Naseri, Hayes, and DeÂ Cristofaro 2020; Sun etÂ al. 2019) have shown the effectiveness of norm bounding in defense against poisoning attacks by malicious clients.

4 Computation/Communication and Utility Tradeoff in FedPerm

Each FedPerm client perturbs its local update (vector xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} containing dğ‘‘d parameters) with randomizer â„›dsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{R}^{d} which is Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}-LDP, and then shuffles its parameters. We use the Laplacian mechanism as the randomizer. Based on the nÃ¤ive composition theorem from LemmaÂ 2.2, the client perturbs each parameter value with â„›â„›\mathcal{R} which satisfies Îµwâ€‹dsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{wd}-LDP where Îµwâ€‹d=Îµddsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğœ€ğ‘‘ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{wd}=\frac{\varepsilon_{d}}{d} (AppendixÂ C contains additional details). CorollaryÂ 4.1 shows the privacy amplification from Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}-LDP to (Îµâ„“,Î´â„“)subscriptğœ€â„“subscriptğ›¿â„“(\varepsilon_{\ell},\delta_{\ell})-DP after the parameter shuffling. CorollaryÂ 4.1 is derived from CorollaryÂ 2.1, by substituting the number of participating clients nğ‘›n by the number of parameters dğ‘‘d in the model.

Corollary 4.1

If â„›â„›\mathcal{R} is Îµwâ€‹dsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{wd}-LDP, where Îµwâ€‹dâ‰¤logâ¡(d/logâ¡(1/Î´â„“))/2subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘ğ‘‘1subscriptğ›¿â„“2\varepsilon_{wd}\leq\log{(d/\log{(1/\delta_{\ell})})}/2, FedPerm â„±=ğ’œâˆ˜ğ’®dâˆ˜â„›dâ„±ğ’œsubscriptğ’®ğ‘‘superscriptâ„›ğ‘‘\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{A}\circ\mathcal{S}_{d}\circ\mathcal{R}^{d} satisfies (Îµâ„“,Î´â„“)subscriptğœ€â„“subscriptğ›¿â„“(\varepsilon_{\ell},\delta_{\ell})-DP with Îµâ„“=Oâ€‹((1âˆ§Îµwâ€‹d)â€‹eÎµwâ€‹dâ€‹logâ¡(1/Î´â„“)/d)subscriptğœ€â„“ğ‘‚1subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘’subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘1subscriptğ›¿â„“ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{\ell}=O((1\wedge\varepsilon_{wd})e^{\varepsilon_{wd}}\sqrt{\log{(1/\delta_{\ell})}/d}).

Thus, larger the number of parameters in the model, greater is the privacy amplification. With large models containing millions or billions of parameters, the privacy amplification can be immense. However, the model dimensionality also affects the computation (and communication) cost in FedPerm. Each FedPerm client generates a dğ‘‘d-dimensional PIR query for every parameter in the model, resulting in a PIR query matrix containing d2superscriptğ‘‘2d^{2} entries. This results in a quadratic increase in client encryption time, server aggregation time, and client-server communication bandwidth consumption. This increase in communication, and more importantly computation, resources is simply infeasible for large models containing billions of parameters. To address this problem FedPerm introduces additional hyperparameters that present an interesting trade off between computation/communication overheads and model utility.

4.1 FedPerm with Smaller Shuffling Pattern

Instead of shuffling all the dğ‘‘d parameters, the FedPerm client can partition its parameters into several identically sized windows, and shuffle the parameters in each window with the same shuffling pattern. Thus, instead of creating a very large random shuffling pattern Ï€ğœ‹\pi with dğ‘‘d indices (i.e., Ï€=RandomPermutationsâ€‹[1,d]ğœ‹RandomPermutations1ğ‘‘\pi=\textsc{RandomPermutations}[1,d]), each client creates a shuffling pattern with k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} indices (i.e., Ï€=RandomPermutationsâ€‹[1,k1]ğœ‹RandomPermutations1subscriptğ‘˜1\pi=\textsc{RandomPermutations}[1,k_{1}]), and shuffles (ğ’®k1subscriptğ’®subscriptğ‘˜1\mathcal{S}_{k_{1}}) each window with these random indices.

The window size k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} is a new FedPerm hyperparameter that can be used to control the computation/communication and model utility trade off. Once we set the size of shuffling pattern to k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, each client needs to perform dâ‹…k1â‹…ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1d\cdot k_{1} encryptions and consumes Oâ€‹(dâ‹…k1)ğ‘‚â‹…ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1O(d\cdot k_{1}) network bandwidth to send its PIR queries to the server.

Superwindow: A shuffling window size of k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, partitions each FedPerm client uğ‘¢uâ€™s local update xusubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢x_{u} (dğ‘‘d parameters) into w=d/k1ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1w=d/k_{1} windows, each containing k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} parameters. Each FedPerm client, independently from other FedPerm clients, chooses its shuffling pattern Ï€ğœ‹\pi uniformly at random with indices âˆˆ[1,k1]absent1subscriptğ‘˜1\in[1,k_{1}], and shuffles each window with this pattern. This means that every position jğ‘—j (1â‰¤jâ‰¤k11ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜11\leq j\leq k_{1}) in each window kğ‘˜k (1â‰¤kâ‰¤w1ğ‘˜ğ‘¤1\leq k\leq w) will have the same permutation index (Ï€jsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘—\pi_{j}). Thus all of the jtâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘¡â„j^{th} positioned parameters (xu(k,j)â€‹forâ€‹â€„1â‰¤kâ‰¤wsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘—for1ğ‘˜ğ‘¤x_{u}^{(k,j)}\;\text{for}\;1\leq k\leq w) will contain the value from the Ï€jtâ€‹hsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘—ğ‘¡â„\pi_{j}^{th} slot in window kğ‘˜k. For a given index jğ‘—j (1â‰¤jâ‰¤k11ğ‘—subscriptğ‘˜11\leq j\leq k_{1}), we define a superwindow as the set of all of the parameters xu(k,j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢ğ‘˜ğ‘—x_{u}^{(k,j)} for 1â‰¤kâ‰¤w1ğ‘˜ğ‘¤1\leq k\leq w. If we structure the parameter vector xusubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¢x_{u} (with dğ‘‘d parameters) as â„k1Ã—wsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘¤\mathbb{R}^{k_{1}\times w} (a matrix with k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} rows and wğ‘¤w columns), each row of this matrix is a superwindow.

FigureÂ 2 depicts an example model containing 121212 parameters Î¸=[Î¸1,Î¸2,â€¦,Î¸12]ğœƒsubscriptğœƒ1subscriptğœƒ2â€¦subscriptğœƒ12\theta=[\theta_{1},\theta_{2},...,\theta_{12}]. The original FedPerm algorithm mandates a shuffling pattern Ï€ğœ‹\pi with 121212 indices âˆˆ[1,12]absent112\in[1,12], where the PIR query generates 12Ã—12=144121214412\times 12=144 encryptions. However, a shuffling pattern Ï€ğœ‹\pi of three indices k1=3subscriptğ‘˜13k_{1}=3 (Ï€=[3,1,2]ğœ‹312\pi=[3,1,2] in the figure) requires only 3Ã—3=93393\times 3=9 encryptions. This shuffling pattern creates 444 windows of size 333 (red boxes in the 2-D matrix in the figure), and each row in the 2-D matrix, represented more succintly by [Î˜A,Î˜B,Î˜C]subscriptÎ˜ğ´subscriptÎ˜ğµsubscriptÎ˜ğ¶[\Theta_{A},\Theta_{B},\Theta_{C}], itself constitutes a superwindow. The shuffling pattern Ï€=[3,1,2]ğœ‹312\pi=[3,1,2] applied to Î¸=[Î˜A,Î˜B,Î˜C]ğœƒsubscriptÎ˜ğ´subscriptÎ˜ğµsubscriptÎ˜ğ¶\theta=[\Theta_{A},\Theta_{B},\Theta_{C}] swaps entire superwindows to give ğ’®k1â€‹(Î¸)=[Î˜C,Î˜A,Î˜B]subscriptğ’®subscriptğ‘˜1ğœƒsubscriptÎ˜ğ¶subscriptÎ˜ğ´subscriptÎ˜ğµ\mathcal{S}_{k_{1}}(\theta)=[\Theta_{C},\Theta_{A},\Theta_{B}].

Shuffling of superwindows, instead of individual parameters, leads to a significant reduction in the computation (and communication) overheads for FedPerm clients. However, this comes at the cost of smaller privacy amplification. CorollaryÂ 4.2 shows the privacy amplification of FedPerm from Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}-LDP to (Îµâ„“,Î´â„“)subscriptğœ€â„“subscriptğ›¿â„“(\varepsilon_{\ell},\delta_{\ell})-DP after superwindow shuffling (with window size k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}). After applying the randomizer â„›â„›\mathcal{R} that is Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}-LDP on the local parameters, each superwindow is Îµwsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\varepsilon_{w}-LDP where Îµw=wâ‹…Îµwâ€‹d=dk1â‹…Îµwâ€‹d=Îµdk1subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤â‹…ğ‘¤subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘â‹…ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğœ€ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1\varepsilon_{w}=w\cdot\varepsilon_{wd}=\frac{d}{k_{1}}\cdot\varepsilon_{wd}=\frac{\varepsilon_{d}}{k_{1}}. Since we are shuffling the superwindows, we can derive CorollaryÂ 4.2 for FedPerm by setting the shuffling pattern size to k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} from CorollaryÂ 2.1.

Corollary 4.2

For FedPerm â„±=ğ’œâˆ˜ğ’®k1âˆ˜â„›wâ„±ğ’œsubscriptğ’®subscriptğ‘˜1superscriptâ„›ğ‘¤\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{A}\circ\mathcal{S}_{k_{1}}\circ\mathcal{R}^{w} with window size k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, where â„›wsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘¤\mathcal{R}^{w} is Îµwsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\varepsilon_{w}-LDP and Îµwâ‰¤logâ¡(k1/logâ¡(1/Î´â„“))/2subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘˜11subscriptğ›¿â„“2\varepsilon_{w}\leq\log{(k_{1}/\log{(1/\delta_{\ell})})}/2, the amplified privacy is Îµâ„“=O((1âˆ§Îµw)eÎµwlogâ¡(1/Î´â„“)/k1\varepsilon_{\ell}=O((1\wedge\varepsilon_{w})e^{\varepsilon_{w}}\sqrt{\log{(1/\delta_{\ell})}/k_{1}}.

4.2 FedPerm with Multiple Shuffling Patterns

An additional way to adjust the computation/communication vs. utility trade off is by using multiple shuffling patterns. Each FedPerm client chooses k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} shuffling patterns {Ï€1,â€¦,Ï€k2}subscriptğœ‹1â€¦subscriptğœ‹subscriptğ‘˜2\{\pi_{1},\dots,\pi_{k_{2}}\} uniformly at random where each Ï€i=RandomPermutationsâ€‹[1,k1]â€‹forâ€‹â€„1â‰¤iâ‰¤k2subscriptğœ‹ğ‘–RandomPermutations1subscriptğ‘˜1for1ğ‘–subscriptğ‘˜2\pi_{i}=\textsc{RandomPermutations}[1,k_{1}]\;\text{for}\;1\leq i\leq k_{2}. Then, each FedPerm client partitions the dğ‘‘d parameters into d/k1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1d/k_{1} windows, where it permutes the parameters of window kğ‘˜k (1â‰¤kâ‰¤d/k11ğ‘˜ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜11\leq k\leq d/k_{1}) with shuffling pattern Ï€iâ€‹s.t.â€‹i=kâ€‹modâ€‹k2subscriptğœ‹ğ‘–s.t.ğ‘–ğ‘˜modsubscriptğ‘˜2\pi_{i}\;\text{s.t.}\;i=k\;\text{mod}\;k_{2}. In this case, each FedPerm client needs k2â‹…k12â‹…subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜12k_{2}\cdot k_{1}^{2} encryptions to generate the PIR queries.

FigureÂ 3 shows FedPerm for d=12ğ‘‘12d=12, k1=3subscriptğ‘˜13k_{1}=3 and k2=2subscriptğ‘˜22k_{2}=2, i.e., there are two shuffling patterns Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1} (shown with red box) and Ï€2subscriptğœ‹2\pi_{2} (shown with blue box) and each one has 3 shuffling indices. In this example, the client partitions the 12 parameters into 444 windows that it shuffles with Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1} (1st and 3rd windows) and Ï€2subscriptğœ‹2\pi_{2} (2nd and 4th windows). This example is equivalent to an FL scneario with two external inter-model shufflers (with shuffling patterns Ï€1,Ï€2subscriptğœ‹1subscriptğœ‹2\pi_{1},\pi_{2}) and three FL clients (A,B,Cğ´ğµğ¶A,B,C). Each client sends 222 (w=d/(k1â€‹k2)ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2w=d/(k_{1}k_{2})) parameters to each shuffler for shuffling with other clients. Two different shuffling patterns Ï€1subscriptğœ‹1\pi_{1} and Ï€2subscriptğœ‹2\pi_{2} are applied on [Î˜Aâ€‹1,Î˜Bâ€‹1,Î˜Câ€‹1]subscriptÎ˜ğ´1subscriptÎ˜ğµ1subscriptÎ˜ğ¶1[\Theta_{A1},\Theta_{B1},\Theta_{C1}] and [Î˜Aâ€‹2,Î˜Bâ€‹2,Î˜Câ€‹2]subscriptÎ˜ğ´2subscriptÎ˜ğµ2subscriptÎ˜ğ¶2[\Theta_{A2},\Theta_{B2},\Theta_{C2}] respectively.

When we have k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} shuffling patterns and each shuffling pattern has k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} indices, the size of each superwindow is w=d/(k1â€‹k2)ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2w=d/(k_{1}k_{2}). Therefore, each client perturbs each superwindow with a randomizer â„›wsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘¤\mathcal{R}^{w} that satisfies Îµwsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\varepsilon_{w}-LDP where Îµw=wâ‹…Îµwâ€‹d=dk1â€‹k2â‹…Îµwâ€‹d=Îµdk1â€‹k2subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤â‹…ğ‘¤subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘â‹…ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤ğ‘‘subscriptğœ€ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2\varepsilon_{w}=w\cdot\varepsilon_{wd}=\frac{d}{k_{1}k_{2}}\cdot\varepsilon_{wd}=\frac{\varepsilon_{d}}{k_{1}k_{2}}. Take Îµwsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\varepsilon_{w} to CorollaryÂ 2.1 on the superwindows to find the amplified local privacy and then using strong composition in LemmaÂ 2.3 we can easily derive the TheoremÂ 4.3 for FedPerm with ğ’®k1k2superscriptsubscriptğ’®subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2\mathcal{S}_{k_{1}}^{k_{2}}.

Theorem 4.3

For FedPerm â„±=ğ’œâˆ˜ğ’®k1k2âˆ˜â„›wâ„±ğ’œsuperscriptsubscriptğ’®subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptâ„›ğ‘¤\mathcal{F}=\mathcal{A}\circ\mathcal{S}_{k_{1}}^{k_{2}}\circ\mathcal{R}^{w} with window size k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, and k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} shuffling patterns, where â„›wsuperscriptâ„›ğ‘¤\mathcal{R}^{w} is Îµwsubscriptğœ€ğ‘¤\varepsilon_{w}-LDP and Îµwâ‰¤logâ¡(k1/logâ¡((k2+1)/Î´â„“))/2subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘˜21subscriptğ›¿â„“2\varepsilon_{w}\leq\log{(k_{1}/\log{((k_{2}+1)/\delta_{\ell})})}/2, the amplified privacy is Îµâ„“=Oâ€‹((1âˆ§Îµw)â€‹eÎµwâ€‹logâ¡(k2/Î´â„“)â€‹k2/k1)subscriptğœ€â„“ğ‘‚1subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤superscriptğ‘’subscriptğœ€ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ›¿â„“subscriptğ‘˜2subscriptğ‘˜1\varepsilon_{\ell}=O((1\wedge\varepsilon_{w})e^{\varepsilon_{w}}\log{(k_{2}/\delta_{\ell})}\sqrt{k_{2}/k_{1}}).

4.3 Privacy Analysis

In FigureÂ 4, we show the relationship of our introduced varibales k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d} and dğ‘‘d on the privacy amplification in FedPerm. FigureÂ 4(a) shows the privacy amplification effect from Îµdsubscriptğœ€ğ‘‘\varepsilon_{d}-LDP to (Îµâ„“,Î´â„“subscriptğœ€â„“subscriptğ›¿â„“\varepsilon_{\ell},\delta_{\ell})-DP for the local model updates after shuffling with k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} shuffling patterns each with size of k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}. We can see that each client can use larger shuffling patterns (i.e. , increasing k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}) or more shuffling patterns (i.e., increasing k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}) and get larger privacy amplification. However, this comes with a price where this imposes more computation/communication burden on the clients to create the PIR queries as they need to encrypt k2Ã—k12subscriptğ‘˜2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜12k_{2}\times k_{1}^{2} values and send them to the server, and it also imposes higher computation on the server as it should multiply larger matrices. FigureÂ 4(b) shows the amplification of privacy for fixed value of k1=100,k2=10formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘˜1100subscriptğ‘˜210k_{1}=100,k_{2}=10 for various model sizes. From this figure we can see that if we want to provide same privacy level for larger models, we need to increase values of k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} or k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} (i.e. more computation/communication cost).

5 Experiments

In this section, we investigate the utility and computation trade offs in FedPerm. We use MNIST dataset and a logistic regression model with d=7850ğ‘‘7850d=7850 parameters to evaluate these trade offs.

5.1 Comparison with Baselines

We compare our results with following baselines: (a) FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al. 2017) with no privacy, (b) CDP-FLÂ (Brendan etÂ al. 2018; Geyer, Klein, and Nabi 2017), (c) LDP-FLÂ (Wang etÂ al. 2019; Liu etÂ al. 2020) with Gaussian Mechanism.

FigureÂ 5(a) shows the test accuracy of that model that was trained using different FL algorithms running for T=50ğ‘‡50T=50 rounds. The MNIST dataset is divided across n=15ğ‘›15n=15 clients with a Dirichlet distribution. FigureÂ 5(b) shows the test accuracy for these algorithms per FL round when the total privacy budget is fixed to Îµ=4.0ğœ€4.0\varepsilon=4.0. We compared two versions of FedPerm in these experiments: (a) FedPerm with k1=400subscriptğ‘˜1400k_{1}=400 and k2=1subscriptğ‘˜21k_{2}=1 which is a â€œlightâ€ version where encryption and decryption time at clients takes around 52.252.252.2 and 2.42.42.4 seconds respectively. It also imposes 212121 minutes computation time at the server. (b) FedPerm with k1=800subscriptğ‘˜1800k_{1}=800 and k2=10subscriptğ‘˜210k_{2}=10 which is a â€œheavyâ€ version where client encryption, decryption, and server aggregation time takes around 32.132.132.1 minutes, 2.42.42.4 seconds and 16.416.416.4 hours respectively.

As we mentioned earlier, FedPerm provides a trade-off between privacy amplification and compute resources â€“ larger the values of k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} and k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, greater are the compute resources for training, which in turn provides higher privacy amplification that results in better model utility. The heavy version of FedPerm needs more resources to be as fast as the lighter version, but it can provide much more utility (because the privacy amplification is larger so the amount of noise is added is smaller). For instance, after T=50ğ‘‡50T=50, and total privacy budget (4.0,1â€‹eâˆ’5)4.01superscriptğ‘’5(4.0,1e^{-5}), the heavy version provides 72.38%percent72.3872.38\% test accuracy while the light version provides 32.85%percent32.8532.85\% test accuracy. From these figures we can see if we invest enough computation resources in FedPerm, we can provide higher utility compared to CDP-FL, without trusting the FedPerm server. Non-private FedAvg, CDP-FL and LDP-FL also provides 91.02%percent91.0291.02\%, 53.50%percent53.5053.50\%, and 13.74%percent13.7413.74\% test accuracies for the same total (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta) respectively.

5.2 Time Analysis

We evaluate the impacts of our hyperparameters k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, nğ‘›n, and dğ‘‘ds on the encryption, decryption and sever aggregation time in FigureÂ 6. We use Paillier encryption system and we use a key size of 204820482048 bits in our experiments. For measuring time, we use 64CPUs and 64GB memory for the client and server simulations. Note that we opt to not use GPU as model training is not a bottleneck in our system compared to HE operations. Also note that these figures are data independent as we are working with encryption and decryption and homomorphic multiplication with plaintext and homomorphic addition.

Client encryption time: In FedPerm, each client must do k12â‹…k2â‹…superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘˜2k_{1}^{2}\cdot k_{2} encryptions for its query, therefore client encryption time has a quadratic and linear relationship with window size (k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}) and number of shuffling patterns (k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}) respectively (FiguresÂ 6(a) andÂ 6(b)). We also show in FigureÂ 4 that increasing the k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} has more impact (close to quadratic impact) compared to increasing k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} on the privacy amplification. This means that if we invest more computation resources on the clients and are able to do more encryption, we get greater privacy amplification by parameter shuffling. For instance, when we increase the k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} from 100100100 to 200200200 (while fixing k2=1subscriptğ‘˜21k_{2}=1), the average client encryption time increases from 3.43.43.4 to 13.113.113.1 seconds for d=7850ğ‘‘7850d=7850 parameters. And while fixing the k1=100subscriptğ‘˜1100k_{1}=100, if we increase the number of shuffling patterns from 111 to 101010, the encryption time goes from 3.43.43.4 to 32.732.732.7 seconds. When we fix the value of k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} and k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, the number of encryption is fixed at the clients, so the encryption time would be constant if we increase the number of parameters (dğ‘‘d) each round (FigureÂ 6(c)).

Client decryption time: Changing k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, and nğ‘›n does not have any impact on decryption time, as each client should decrypt dğ‘‘d parameters (FiguresÂ 6(a) andÂ 6(b)). In figureÂ 6(c), we show the linear relationship of decryption time and number of parameters. For instance by increasing the number of parameters from 105superscript105{10}^{5} to 106superscript106{10}^{6}, the decryption time increases from 1.011.011.01 to 9.919.919.91 seconds.

Server aggregation time: In FedPerm, the server first multiplies the encrypted binary mask to the corresponding shuffled model parameters for each client participating in the training round, and then sums the encrypted unshuffled parameters to compute the encrypted global model. We employ joblib to parallelize matrix multiplication over superwindows. Thus, larger the superwindows greater is the parallelism. However, as we increase k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} and/or k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} the superwindow size goes down, and hence the parallelism, which leads to increase in running time as observed in FiguresÂ 6(a) and Â 6(b). Moreover, increasing nğ‘›n, dğ‘‘d has a linear relationship with server aggregation time (FigureÂ 6(c) andÂ 6(d)). For instance, when we increase the nğ‘›n from 555 to 101010 the server aggregation time increases from 157.47157.47157.47 to 326.72326.72326.72 seconds for d=7850ğ‘‘7850d=7850, k1=100subscriptğ‘˜1100k_{1}=100, and k2=1subscriptğ‘˜21k_{2}=1.

6 Conclusion

We presented FedPerm, a new FL algorithm that combines LDP, intra-model parameter shuffling at the federation clients, and a cPIR based technique for parameter aggregation at the federation server to deliver both client data privacy and robustness from model poisoning attacks. Our intra-model parameter shuffling significantly amplifies the LDP guarantee for clientsâ€™ training data. The cPIR based technique we employ allows cryptographic parameter aggregation at the server. At the same time, the server clips the clientsâ€™ parameter updates to ensure that model poisoning attacks by adversarial clients are effectively thwarted. We also presented windowing hyperparameters in FedPerm that let us trade off compute resources with model utility. Our empirical evaluation on the MNIST dataset demonstrates FedPermâ€™s privacy amplification benefits and studies the trade off between computation and model utility. We leave the study of extensions to FedPermÂ â€“ (i) an additional dimension of the hyperparameters (k3subscriptğ‘˜3k_{3}) that takes the computation-utility trade offs to hypercube space (see AppendixÂ E), (ii) plugging in other PIR protocols, and (iii) combining an external client shuffler with FedPermÂ â€“ to future work.

Appendix A Threat Models

In this section, we describe two threat models that are of interest to our work, and illustrated in FigureÂ 7.

A.1 Honest-but-Curious Aggregator

In this threat model, we assume that the server correctly follows the aggregation algorithm, but may try to learn clientsâ€™ private information by inspecting the model updates sent by the participants. This is a common assumption that previous worksÂ (Zhang etÂ al. 2020; Xu etÂ al. 2019; Bonawitz etÂ al. 2017; Truex etÂ al. 2019) also consider. For creating the PIR queries, we use PaillierÂ (Paillier 1999) homomorphic encryption. We explain different homomorphic encryption systems that we use in AppendixÂ D.3. Before starting FedPerm, we need a key server to generate and distribute the keys for the homomorphic encryption (HE). A key server generates a pair of public and secret homomorphic keys (Pâ€‹k,Sâ€‹k)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘†ğ‘˜(Pk,Sk), sends them to the clients, and sends only the public key to the server. Either a trusted external key server or a leader client can be responsible for this role. For the leader client, similar to previous worksÂ (Zhang etÂ al. 2020), before the training starts, the FL server randomly selects a client as the leader. The leader client then generates the keys and distributes them to the clients and the server as above.

The steps of FedPerm for this threat model (FigureÂ 7(a)) are as follows: (1) The pair of keys are distributed by the key server to all the clients. (2) In each round of training, the clients learn their local updates, generate encrypted PIR query and shuffled parameters, and send them to the server. Next, the server aggregates the updates, and sends the aggregated update to the clients. (3) Each client can decrypt the encrypted global parameters received from the server using the private key and updates its model.

A.2 Curious and Colluding Clients

In this threat model, we assume that some clients may collude with the FL server to get private information about a victim client by inspecting its model update. For this threat model, we use thresholded PaillierÂ (DamgÃ¥rd and Jurik 2001). In the thresholded Paillier scheme, the secret key is divided to multiple shares, and each share is given to a different client. For this threat model, we need an external key server that generates the keys and sends (Pâ€‹k,Sâ€‹ki)ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–(Pk,Sk_{i}) to each client, and sends the public key to the server. Now each client can partially decrypt an encrypted message, but if less than a threshold, say tğ‘¡t, combine their partial decrypted values, they cannot get any information about the real message. On the other hand, if we combine â‰¥tabsentğ‘¡\geq t partial decrypted values, we can recover the secret. We explain how thresholeded Paillier scheme works in AppendixÂ D.3.

The steps of FedPerm for this threat model (FigureÂ 7(b)) are as follows: (1) The pairs of keys are distributed to the clients by the key server. (2) In each round of training, the clients learn their local updates,generate encrypted PIR query and shuffled parameters, and send them to the server. Next, the server aggregates the local updates to produce global model update (which is encrypted). (3) The server randomly chooses tğ‘¡t clients to partially decrypt the global model update. The FedPerm server sends the encrypted global update to these clients. (4) Each client decrypts the global model with its specific partial secret key Sâ€‹kiğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–Sk_{i}, and sends the result back to the server. (5) The server first authenticates each partial decryption that is done by the true Sâ€‹kiğ‘†subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–Sk_{i} (by a zero-knowledge proof provided by thresholded PaillierÂ (DamgÃ¥rd and Jurik 2001)). Then the FedPerm server combines the partial decrypted updates and broadcasts plain unshuffled model updates to all the clients for the next round of FedPerm.

At present our implementation of FedPerm does not support this threat model, and we leave it for future work.

Appendix D Background

D.1 Robustness to poisoning attacks

Most of the distributed learning algorithms, including FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al. 2017), operate on mutually untrusted clients and server. This makes distributed learning susceptible to the threat of poisoningÂ (Kairouz etÂ al. 2019; Shejwalkar etÂ al. 2021). A poisoning adversary can either own or control a few of FL clients, called malicious clients, and instruct them to share malicious updates with the central server in order to reduce the performance of the global model. There are two approaches to poisoning FL: untargetedÂ (Baruch, Gilad, and Goldberg 2019; Fang etÂ al. 2020; Shejwalkar and Houmansadr 2021) attacks aim to reduce the utility of global model on arbitrary test inputs; and backdoorÂ (Bagdasaryan etÂ al. 2020; Wang etÂ al. 2020; Xie etÂ al. 2019) attacks aim to reduce the utility on test inputs that contain a specific signal called the trigger.

In order to make FL robust to the presence of such malicious clients, the literature has designed various robust aggregation rules (AGR)Â (Blanchard etÂ al. 2017; Mhamdi, Guerraoui, and Rouault 2018; Yin etÂ al. 2018; Mozaffari, Shejwalkar, and Houmansadr 2021), which aim to remove or attenuate the updates that are more likely to be malicious according to some criterion. For instance, Multi-krumÂ (Blanchard etÂ al. 2017) repeatedly removes updates that are far from the geometric median of all the updates, and Trimmed-meanÂ (Yin etÂ al. 2018) removes the largest and smallest values of each update dimension and calculates the mean of the remaining values. It is not possible to use these AGRs in secure aggregation as the parameters are encrypted.

D.2 Private Information Retrieval (PIR)

Private information retrieval (PIR) is a technique to provide query privacy to users when fetching sensitive records from untrusted database servers. That is, PIR enables users to query and retrieve specific records from untrusted database server(s) in a way that the servers cannot identify the records retrieved. There are two major types of PIR protocols. The first type is computational PIR (CPIR)Â (Chang 2004) in which the security of the protocol relies on the computational difficulty of solving a mathematical problem in polynomial time by the servers, e.g., factorization of large numbers. Most of the CPIR protocols are designed to be run by a single database server, and therefore to minimize privacy leakage they perform their heavy computations on the whole database (even if a single entry has been queried). Most of these protocols use homomorphic encryption (SectionÂ D.3) to make their queries private. The second major class of PIR is information-theoretic PIR (ITPIR)Â (Mozaffari and Houmansadr 2020). ITPIR protocols provide information-theoretic security, however, existing designs need to be run on more than one database servers, and they need to assume that the servers do not collude. Our work uses computational PIR (cPIR) protocols to make the shuffling private.

D.3 Homomorphic Encryption (HE)

Homomorphic encryption (HE) allows application of certain arithmetic operations (e.g., addition or multiplication) on the ciphertexts without decrypting them. Many recent worksÂ (Chang 2004) advocate using partial HE, that only supports addition, to make the FL aggregation secure. In this section we describe two important HE systems that we use in our paper.

Paillier An additively homomorphic encryption system provides following property:

Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹(m1)âˆ˜Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹(m2)=Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹(m1+m2)ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘š1ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘š2ğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘subscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘š2Enc(m_{1})\circ Enc(m_{2})=Enc(m_{1}+m_{2}) (9)

where âˆ˜\circ is a defined function on top of the ciphertexts.

In these works, the clients encrypt their updates, send them to the server, then the server can calculate their sum (using the âˆ˜\circ operation) and sends back the encrypted results to the clients. Now, the clients can decrypt the global model locally and update their models. Using HE in these scenario does not produce any accuracy loss because no noise will be added to the model parameters during the encryption and decryption process.

Thresholded Paillier InÂ (DamgÃ¥rd and Jurik 2001), the authors extend the Paillier system and proposed a thresholded version. In the thresholded Paillier scheme, the secret key is divided to multiple shares, and each share is given to a different participant. Now each participant can partially decrypt an encrypted message, but if less than a threshold, say tğ‘¡t, combine their partial decrypted values, they cannot get any information about the real message. On the other hand, if we combine â‰¥tabsentğ‘¡\geq t partial decrypted values, we can recover the secret. Appendix E Discussion and Future Work

Utilizing recursion in cPIR. A solution to reduce the number encryptions and upload bandwidth at the clients would be using recursion in our cPIR. In this technique, the dataset is represented by a k3subscriptğ‘˜3k_{3}-dimensional hypercube, and this allows the PIR client to prepare and send k3â€‹dk3subscriptğ‘˜3subscriptğ‘˜3ğ‘‘k_{3}\sqrt[k_{3}]{d} encrypted values where k3subscriptğ‘˜3k_{3} would be another hyperparameter. For future work, we can use this technique and reduce the number of encryptions which makes the upload bandwidth consumption lower too. For instance, if we have one shuffling pattern k2=1subscriptğ‘˜21k_{2}=1, the number of encryption decreases from k1â€‹dsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘k_{1}d to k3â€‹k1k3â€‹dsubscriptğ‘˜3subscriptğ‘˜3subscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘‘k_{3}\sqrt[k_{3}]{k_{1}}d.

Plugging newer PIR protocol. FedPerm utilizes cPIR for private aggregation, and in particular we use Â (Chang 2004) which is based on Paillier. However, any other cPIR protocol can be used in FedPerm. For example, SealPIRÂ (Angel etÂ al. 2018) can be used to reduce the number of encryptions at the client. SealPIR is based on a SEAL which is a lattice based fully HE. The authors show how to compress the PIR queries and achieve size reduction of up to 274Ã—274\times. We defer analyzing FedPerm with other cPIR schemes to future work.

Combination of an external client shuffler for more privacy amplification. For further privacy amplification, we can use an external shuffler that shuffles the nğ‘›n sampled clientsâ€™ updates similar to FLAMEÂ (Liu etÂ al. 2021). For future work, we can use double amplification by first shuffling the parameters at the clients (i.e. , detaching the parameter values from their position) and then shuffle the clientâ€™s updates at the external shuffler (i.e., detaching the updates from their clientâ€™s ID).
